title: Riot is about to make a Big Mistake.
body:
Let me start by saying this is NOT a whine thread.

Now, Riot is playing to remove item sets in season 7, this may not be an issue for you, but for some players this is a problem. Lets start by asking the question: "What does Riot gain from removing item sets?" The answer is nothing. As it stands, removing item sets would give nothing positive to players, only cause upset. I use item sets myself, because memorizing the right builds for different situations is very difficult for multiple champions. All im saying is Riot, dont make another mistake you will end up regretting, for the community and your company's sake, please dont remove Item Sets.        

Your long-time fan, SummonersFowl

what does the new client do better?

from what i have seen so far, there is an addition of art assets, transition animations, sounds, et cetera to the client... which i will not like.

The old client used a very outdated technology, that made very difficult for riot to ever change anything and every time they change something the needed to rebuild part of the code, also they needed specific programmer for the old code. The new client is generally better and make implementing things much easier.

Actually, I don't think it's old code or a specific programmer (http://forums.na.leagueoflegends.com/board/showthread.php?t=16318), if you look at Lima Bean's response, most of the languages there are fairly mainstream. It's more likely that when they first created league they didn't expect or plan for how big it would get. To maintain such a large project they would have needed a very good design. What most likely happened is that the design was lacking, inconsistent programming standards, which caused certain things to break when a change was pushed. As an analogy, many people using the kitchen but only one at a time, one person goes to buy apples, places them in the apples basket in the cabinet. Another person, bought some apples and places them in a drawer. Time passes and they realize that the apples are probably bad and should be thrown out, so they go and remove it from the designated apples basket from the appropriate cabinet. Meanwhile they have apples rotting in a drawer. Now imagine a HUGE kitchen pantry that has had years and years of things being put in incorrect places, imagine cleaning that up. It would be pretty difficult and time consuming. It would be easier to just start over, wouldn't it? The upside, because the new client has a better design and presumably there are better programming standards (lesson: put all the apples in the apple basket guys) it should make updates less painful. :)
That is... actually a really amazing analogy. Thank you.
A rioter mentioned the new client is going to be less resource intensive than the original despite looking "flashier" since they've been optimizing it a lot.

Redundant and superfluous art assets are not a negative because they consume computer resources. They are by themselves bad because they consume attention by presenting you with "look at me" moments where you'd rather be thinking or making choices, they make information less clear, they consume space that could otherwise be used for informative purposes OR for giving you some piece and quite to look at some information elsewhere on the page, and because they make you wait for whatever animation is in effect to end before you continue with the menu. 

With respect to Design and art assets, the rule of thumb is this: less is more. The optimal way to design functional things (like a game) is to only slightly overshoot the absolute minimum.

you can not make an un-exciting part of the game exciting by injecting it with art assets. you can't make champion select have more "pizaaz" by added drum rolls and skin portraits and champion quotes. It works exactly twice, and the third time the person who has to go through the process of choosing a champion gets annoyed at being disturbed.

Honestly dude I don't understand this circle Jerk about item sets and am on your side and any other similar side.  

The amount of effort it takes to go in and make an item set for each champ class or champion is about twice the work it takes to memorize where the items are in the big list and or learn how to navigate the menu. For the people who say it isn't organized there's literally a big list of checkable sort boxes and a search bar.  

You have 8 seconds to recall and more if you die.  You should have not only figured out what you're going to be building before you shop in the first place,  but have more than enough time to type the first three letters of the item you want in the search bar.  

Besides there's so many tricks to navigating the menu,  like clicking an item with a same recipe part for another item.  But it all comes back to actually taking the time to learn the system that's in place.  

I mean I'm all for you guys using the tools while they were presented to you,  that's all well and fine.  But times is changing and it's time to move on and adapt.  There's really no other way to go about it.  You can't have your cake and eat it too, this was what riot decided to cut in order to give us a myriad of other features. In a few months you will  all be bitching about the next thing and the only remnants of this will be the 4 or 5 salty forum heads who can't let it go and would care to blame everything on "if I still had items sets". 

There's some things changing that I'm not thrilled about.  But guess what,  riot has changed them,  they have a design path and a goal,  and they are executing it. They've been giving a lot to the community lately as far as wish fulfillment,  stop clawing at every last morsel like a bunch of needy rats.

I only play one or two main roles and champions in ranked. It didn't take that long to make a couple of pages for each, depending on the type of matchup I'm against (heavy-poke, etc). I know how to navigate the shop, but it's still much less difficult and much faster to have the items available more immediately and forgo the navigation altogether, and those extra seconds in-game can make a big difference.

They honestly don't though,  you shop while you are recalling or waiting for mana  or are dead or Any combination of downtime.  Not in the middle of a teamfight.  If you can't get in done in those 12-15 seconds then there's a bigger issue beyond the item sets. 

If the bitch is QoL.  Fine, fair, I guess. But people are acting like they WONT be able to shop now becuase of it or that it will somehow impact the game.  Which is downright absurd as an argument.  

But if the bitch is strictly QoL then call it what it is,  and realize how stupid it sounds.  "I don't like this because it's different and will make my LoL life inconsequentialy harder for a short period of time until I adjust in 4 or so games"

If I can take 2 seconds to shop instead of 12-15, I can use the remaining seconds to think about where the enemy jungler might be, what items I should look to build after this one, how I can avoid doing whatever it was that caused me to die in the future...

Maybe I just think slower than some people, but that extra decision-making time is really useful to me. I'll can certainly shop w/o item sets, I'll just have a little less time for actually playing the game.

Are you serious?

Item sets are what makes it possible to always build different items every game. It lets you put every defensive/offensive/utility in a nicely presented manner so that you are constantly reminded of them. 

The players complaining about item sets are not those who used it to make one build path then never cared anymore, the default recommended item does that well enough. It's the players who actually used the feature as it's meant to be : as a way to quickly see every item that one considers compatible with their champion, or sometimes for very specific niche uses that are still worth being kept in mind. 

It could even be complex pages dedicated to a certain role. I for example had a strictly support set, where I had every item any support would ever buy, from the starting items, to trinkets, to common items like aegis as well as occasional ones like Zhonya or Rylai.

It's like getting rid of Yasuo ult's indicator. Sure, you can see if the enemy is knocked up without it, but it's much better for clarity's sake to have the line pointing towards the enemy.
